_header: Of wine away the moles may ye wash
Note: This stanza also appears as the third stanza of 6830, ‘A tretise for lauandres’, sometimes attrib. to Lydgate. Separate versions of the Latin hexameter couplet (Vinum lacte laua…) occur in London, British Library Harley 3528, f. 38v and London, British Library Royal 17 B.XLVII, f. 3v (with a third concluding line).
_description: On removing spots made by wine, water, and milk — one stanza rhyme royal

BLAdd34360.First Lines:
Of wyne awey the moles may ye wasshIn mylkes white the fletyng oyle
                    spot…
BLAdd34360.Last Lines:
…with water clere I purged and made cleneBut thse iij clensith
                    wyne Mylk and bene
BLAdd34360.Note:
Preceded in the MS by the Latin hexameter couplet of which it is a
                    translation, ‘Vinum lacte laua oleum liquore fabarum / Encaustum vino
                        cetera mundat aqua’.
BLAdd34360.Editions:
Steele,  Robert. 
             “A Stow MS. of Lydgate.” 
             Academy
         45 (No. 1149, 12 May 1894): 395: 395.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
Of wyne awey the moles may ye wassheIn mylkes white the fletynge
                    oyle spot…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
With water clere I purged and made cleneBut these iij clensith wyne
                    Mylk and ber
BLHar2251.Note:
Preceded in the MS by the Latin hexameter couplet of which it is a
                    translation: ‘Vinum lacte laua oleum liquore fabarum / Encaustum vino
                        cetera mundat Aqua’.
BLHar2251.Editions:
Mooney,  Linne R. 
             “Practical Didactic Works in Middle English.” 
         Diss. Toronto, 1981: 399-400.
